query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Quando il settentrïon del primo cielo, 2 che né occaso mai seppe né orto 3 né d’altra nebbia che di colpa velo,
4 e che faceva lì ciascun accorto 5 di suo dover, come ’l più basso face 6 qual temon gira per venire a porto,
7 fermo s’affisse: la gente verace, 8 venuta prima tra ’l grifone ed esso, 9 al carro volse sé come a sua pace;
10 e un di loro, quasi da ciel messo, 11 ‘Veni, sponsa, de Libano’ cantando 12 gridò tre volte, e tutti li altri appresso.
query.result:
**English:**
1 When the north of the first heaven, 2 which never knew setting nor rising, 3 nor any veil of mist except that of sin,
4 and which made everyone there aware 5 of his duty, just as the lowest one does 6 when the rudder turns to bring it to port,
7 stood still, the truthful people, 8 who had come first between the griffin and it, 9 turned to the chariot as to their peace;
10 and one of them, as if sent from heaven, 11 sang “Come, bride, from Lebanon,” 12 and shouted it three times, and all the others followed.
**Old English:**
1 Þa se norðeweard on heofonum ærest, 2 se þe næfre west ne cuðe ne upgang, 3 ne oðre mistes þonne synna wræce,
4 and se þe þær geworhte ælcne wisne 5 his agenre þearfe, swa se niðemesta 6 þonne steorrað stýreð to þam stede,
7 fæste gestod: seo folcgesamnung soðfæst, 8 þe æror com betwux þam griffan and him, 9 to þam cræte gewende swa to hyra sibbe;
10 and an of þam, swa him of heofonum wære, 11 “Veni, sponsa, de Libano” singende 12 clypode þryswa, and ealle þa oðre æfter.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Quali i beati al novissimo bando 14 surgeran presti ognun di sua caverna, 15 la revestita voce alleluiando,
16 cotali in su la divina basterna 17 si levar cento, ad vocem tanti senis, 18 ministri e messaggier di vita etterna.
query.result:
**English:**
13 As the blessed at the final summons 14 will rise up swiftly, each from his cavern, 15 their resurrected voices singing Alleluia,
16 so a hundred rose up on the divine litter 17 at the voice of so venerable an old man, 18 ministers and messengers of eternal life.
**Old English:**
13 Swa ða gesæligan æt ðam æftemestan byde 14 arisan hraðe, ælc of his scræfe, 15 ða ærisenan stefne "Alleluia" singende,
16 swa ða hundteontig on ðam godcundan bæðern 17 arisan, æt ðæs swiðe ealdan mannes stefne, 18 ðegnas and ærendracan ðæs ecan lifes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Tutti dicean: ‘Benedictus qui venis!’, 20 e fior gittando e di sopra e dintorno, 21 ‘Manibus, oh, date lilïa plenis!’.
query.result:
**English:**
19 All were saying: ‘Blessed are you who come!’, 20 and throwing flowers above and all around, 21 ‘Oh, give lilies with your hands full!’.
**Old English:**
19 Ealle cwædon: ‘Benedictus qui venis!’, 20 and streowedon blomon bufon and neoðan, 21 ‘Manibus, oh, date lilïa plenis!’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Io vidi già nel cominciar del giorno 23 la parte orïental tutta rosata, 24 e l’altro ciel di bel sereno addorno;
25 e la faccia del sol nascere ombrata, 26 sì che per temperanza di vapori 27 l’occhio la sostenea lunga fïata:
28 così dentro una nuvola di fiori 29 che da le mani angeliche saliva 30 e ricadeva in giù dentro e di fori,
31 sovra candido vel cinta d’uliva 32 donna m’apparve, sotto verde manto 33 vestita di color di fiamma viva.
query.result:
**English:**
22 I saw already at the beginning of the day 23 the eastern part all rosy, 24 and the other sky adorned with beautiful serenity;
25 and the face of the sun rising shaded, 26 so that because of the moderation of vapors 27 the eye could bear it for a long time:
28 thus within a cloud of flowers 29 that rose from angelic hands 30 and fell back down inside and out,
31 over a white veil, wreathed with olive, 32 a lady appeared to me, beneath a green mantle, 33 dressed in the color of a living flame.
**Old English:**
22 Ic geseah ða gyt on dæges fruman 23 ðone eastdæl ealne rosigne, 24 and ðone oðerne heofon mid beorhtum wederum gefrætewod;
25 and ðære sunnan ansyn up astigendlíc gesceadwis, 26 swa ðæt ðurh gemetgung wætres 27 ðæt eage ða gesihðe lange ðolian mihte:
28 swa innan wolcne blostmena 29 ðe of ðæra engla handa stigon 30 and eft nyðer feollon innan and utan,
31 ofer hwítne slæp mid elebeame bewunden 32 wíf me æteowde, under grægum hrægle 33 gegyred mid liges wynnum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 E lo spirito mio, che già cotanto 35 tempo era stato ch’a la sua presenza 36 non era di stupor, tremando, affranto,
37 sanza de li occhi aver più conoscenza, 38 per occulta virtù che da lei mosse, 39 d’antico amor sentì la gran potenza.
query.result:
**English:**
34 And my spirit, which had been for so long 35 a time that it was not in its presence 36 free from amazement, trembling, broken,
37 without having any more knowledge of my eyes, 38 through a hidden power that moved from her, 39 felt the great power of ancient love.
**Old English:**
34 And min gast, ðe ðær lange ær 35 wæs ðurh ðone miclan fyrst ðe he ðær wæs 36 butan wundre, bifiende, gebrocen,
37 butan ðæs gesihðes ðe he ær hæfde, 38 ðurh ða digelan miht ðe of hire com, 39 ðæs ealdan lufu ða miclan strengðe ongeat.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Tosto che ne la vista mi percosse 41 l’alta virtù che già m’avea trafitto 42 prima ch’io fuor di püerizia fosse,
43 volsimi a la sinistra col respitto 44 col quale il fantolin corre a la mamma 45 quando ha paura o quando elli è afflitto,
46 per dicere a Virgilio: ‘Men che dramma 47 di sangue m’è rimaso che non tremi: 48 conosco i segni de l’antica fiamma’.
query.result:
**English:**
40 As soon as my sight was struck by 41 the noble power that had already pierced me 42 before I was out of boyhood,
43 I turned to the left with the same instinct 44 with which a little child runs to its mother 45 when it is frightened or when it is distressed,
46 to say to Virgil: ‘Less than a dram 47 of blood is left in me that does not tremble: 48 I recognize the signs of the old flame’.
**Old English:**
40 Swa rathe swa on ðære gesyhðe me ætberst 41 se hehsta mægen ðe me ær ðurhwundode 42 ær ðam ðe ic of cildhade wære,
43 ic me wende to ðære wynstran mid ðam geleafan 44 mid ðam se lytla cnapa rynð to ðære meder 45 ðonne he forht bið oððe he gedrefed bið,
46 ðæt ic sæde to Firgile: ‘Læsse ðonne an dram 47 mines blodes me is læfed ðe ne bifie: 48 ic oncnawe ða tacna ðære ealdan fyres’.

**English:**
49 But Virgil had left us bereft 50 of himself, Virgil the sweetest father, 51 Virgil to whom for my salvation I had said:
52 Nor all that the ancient mother lost 53 availed to keep the cheeks clean of dew, 54 so that, weeping, they did not turn dark again.
**Old English:**
49 Ac Virgilius hæfde us forlætene sceame 50 fram him, Virgilius ðe sweteste fæder, 51 Virgilius ðone ic for minre hæle cwæð:
52 Ne eall ðæt ðe ðeo ealde modor forleas 53 ne mihte ða wlitegan wengan forwærnan, 54 ðæt ða tearas ne gewurðon eft wonne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 «Dante, perché Virgilio se ne vada, 56 non pianger anco, non piangere ancora; 57 ché pianger ti conven per altra spada».
query.result:
**English:**
55 "Dante, why do you weep because Virgil departs, 56 do not weep yet, do not weep yet; 57 for it is fitting for you to weep for another sword."
**Old English:**
55 "Drihten, forðon ðe Virgilius hine gewiteð, 56 ne wep ðu na gyt, ne wep ðu na gyta; 57 forðæm ðe ðe gedafenað ðæt ðu wepe for oðrum sweorde."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Quasi ammiraglio che in poppa e in prora 59 viene a veder la gente che ministra 60 per li altri legni, e a ben far l’incora;
61 in su la sponda del carro sinistra, 62 quando mi volsi al suon del nome mio, 63 che di necessità qui si registra,
64 vidi la donna che pria m’appario 65 velata sotto l’angelica festa, 66 drizzar li occhi ver’ me di qua dal rio.
query.result:
**English:**
58 Like an admiral who on poop and prow 59 comes to see the people who serve 60 on the other ships, and encourages them to do well;
61 on the left side of the chariot, 62 when I turned at the sound of my name, 63 which must be recorded here,
64 I saw the lady who had first appeared to me, 65 veiled beneath the angelic festival, 66 turn her eyes toward me from across the river.
**Old English:**
58 Swa swa scipflotan on stefnan and on bæge 59 cymð to geseonne ða men þe þeniaoð 60 ofer ða oðre scipu, and hi to wel-dæde
61 On ðæs wænes wynstran healfe, 62 ða ic me bewende æt ðæs naman hleopor, 63 ðe her neodunga nemned beoð,
64 ða geseah ic ða ðamne þe me ær æteowde, 65 bewrigen under ðære engliscan wlite, 66 hyre eagan ofer ða ea to me weard gewende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Tutto che ’l vel che le scendea di testa, 68 cerchiato de le fronde di Minerva, 69 non la lasciasse parer manifesta,
70 regalmente ne l’atto ancor proterva 71 continüò come colui che dice 72 e ’l più caldo parlar dietro reserva:
73 «Guardaci ben! Ben son, ben son Beatrice.
query.result:
**English:**
67 All that veil that descended from her head, 68 encircled by the leaves of Minerva, 69 did not prevent her from appearing manifest,
70 regally haughty still in her bearing, 71 she continued like one who speaks 72 and reserves the warmest words for last:
73 “Look at me well! I am indeed, I am indeed Beatrice.
**Old English:**
67 Eall ðæt gewæde ðe hire of heafde feoll, 68 bewunden mid ðære leafan Minerfan, 69 ne lēt hire beon gesýne,
70 cynelice on ðam geðeahte ðeah protere 71 forðferde swa se ðe spricð 72 and ða wyrmestan word æfter healt:
73 “Loca nu wel! Ic eom, ic eom Beatrice.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
74 Come degnasti d’accedere al monte? 75 non sapei tu che qui è l’uom felice?».
76 Li occhi mi cadder giù nel chiaro fonte; 77 ma veggendomi in esso, i trassi a l’erba, 78 tanta vergogna mi gravò la fronte.
query.result:
**English:**
74 How were you deemed worthy to ascend the mountain? 75 Do you not know that here is where man is happy?”.
76 My eyes fell down into the clear spring; 77 but seeing myself in it, I drew them to the grass, 78 so much shame weighed down my brow.
**Old English:**
74 Hu wære ðu wyrðe ðæs ðu ðone munt astige? 75 Ne wast ðu ðæt her is ðæs mannes gesælð?”.
76 Mine eagan feollon niðer on ðone hluttran wæll; 77 ac ða ic ðær geseah me sylfne, ða gewende ic hi to ðære gærsan, 78 swa micel sceamu me ða ðone neb oferwrah.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Così la madre al figlio par superba, 80 com’ ella parve a me; perché d’amaro 81 sente il sapor de la pietade acerba.
query.result:
**English:**
79 Thus the mother spoke proudly to her son, 80 as she appeared to me; for she felt the bitter 81 taste of harsh pity.
**Old English:**
79 Swa ðeos modor ðam suna ða ofermodlice 80 spræc, swa heo ðuhte ða me; forðæm heo ðæs bitran 81 breostceare wætre begoten wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Ella si tacque; e li angeli cantaro 83 di sùbito ‘In te, Domine, speravi’; 84 ma oltre ‘pedes meos’ non passaro.
query.result:
**English:**
82 She was silent; and the angels suddenly sang 83 ‘In te, Domine, speravi’; 84 but they did not go beyond ‘pedes meos’.
**Old English:**
82 Heo ða geswac; ða ða englas sungon 83 of ðam heofonum ‘In te, Domine, speravi’; 84 ac hi ne sungon furðor ðonne ‘pedes meos’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Ella, pur ferma in su la detta coscia 101 del carro stando, a le sustanze pie 102 volse le sue parole così poscia:
103 «Voi vigilate ne l’etterno die, 104 sì che notte né sonno a voi non fura 105 passo che faccia il secol per sue vie;
106 onde la mia risposta è con più cura 107 che m’intenda colui che di là piagne, 108 perché sia colpa e duol d’una misura.
query.result:
**English:**
100 She, still standing firm on the said haunch 101 of the chariot, turned her words thus afterward 102 to the holy substances:
103 "You who watch in the eternal day, 104 so that neither night nor sleep steals from you 105 any step that the world takes on its paths;
106 therefore my answer is with greater care 107 so that he who weeps yonder may understand me, 108 so that his fault and his grief may be of one measure.
**Old English:**
100 Heo, ðeah ðe heo fæste on ðære ylcan sceonce 101 ðæs wænes stode, to ðæm halgum ðingum 102 wende ða hire word ðus æfter ðam:
103 "Ge ðe on ðam ecan dæge waciað, 104 swa ðæt ne niht ne swefn eow ne mæg 105 ænigne ðara staðola forstolen habban 106 ðe ðeos world gewunað on hire wegum faran;
107 for ðon is min andsware mid ðy maran geðylde, 108 ðæt ðe se ðe ðær wepeð ðis gehyre, 109 ðæt his gylt and his reowð sie ðæs ylcan gemætes."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Non pur per ovra de le rote magne, 110 che drizzan ciascun seme ad alcun fine 111 secondo che le stelle son compagne,
112 ma per larghezza di grazie divine, 113 che sì alti vapori hanno a lor piova, 114 che nostre viste là non van vicine,
115 questi fu tal ne la sua vita nova 116 virtüalmente, ch’ogne abito destro 117 fatto averebbe in lui mirabil prova.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Not only because of the revolutions of the great wheels, 110 which direct every seed to some end, 111 according to the constellations that accompany them,
112 but also because of the breadth of divine grace, 113 which sends down such lofty vapors as rain, 114 that our sight cannot reach them,
115 this man was such in his new life, 116 virtually, that every right habit 117 would have made a marvelous demonstration in him.
**Old English:**
109 Nis ðæt an ðurh ðara miclan hweofla wyrp, 110 ða ðone sæd ælces cynnes styrað 111 æfter ðam ðe ða steorran gesceapað,
112 ac ðurh ðara godcundan gyfe ða miclan, 113 ðe swylce heage wætan hæfð to regne, 114 ðæt ure gesyhð ðærto ne mæg gesyne,
115 ðes wæs swylc on his niwan life 116 ðurh ða mihte, ðæt ælc ðeaw ðe god is 117 hæfde on him gewunodlice wundorlice mægen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Ma tanto più maligno e più silvestro 119 si fa ’l terren col mal seme e non cólto, 120 quant’ elli ha più di buon vigor terrestro.
query.result:
**English:**
118 But the land becomes all the more malignant and wild 119 with the bad seed and without cultivation, 120 the more good earthly vigor it has.
**Old English:**
118 Ac swiðe ðe má mænigfealdlícor and ðe wildlícor 119 bið se eorðscýþþ mid ðæm yflum sæde and ungesawen, 120 swá micle swá he hæfð má of ðæs gódlican eorðlícan strengðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Alcun tempo il sostenni col mio volto: 122 mostrando li occhi giovanetti a lui, 123 meco il menava in dritta parte vòlto.
query.result:
**English:**
121 For some time I sustained him with my face, 122 showing him my youthful eyes, 123 and he led me, turned toward the right path.
**Old English:**
121 Sume hwile ic hine fram me sylfum afyrde: 122 ða ic him mine geogoðe eagan æteowde, 123 and he me lædde on ðone rihtan weg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Sì tosto come in su la soglia fui 125 di mia seconda etade e mutai vita, 126 questi si tolse a me, e diessi altrui.
query.result:
**English:**
124 As soon as I was on the threshold 125 of my second age and changed my life, 126 this one took himself from me and gave himself to another.
**Old English:**
124 Swa rathe swa ic on ða swyðran hond 125 lifes weges wæs and worulde brucðe, 126 ða me ðeos mon forlet and oðrum sealde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Né l’impetrare ispirazion mi valse, 134 con le quali e in sogno e altrimenti 135 lo rivocai: sì poco a lui ne calse!
136 Tanto giù cadde, che tutti argomenti 137 a la salute sua eran già corti, 138 fuor che mostrarli le perdute genti.
query.result:
**English:**
133 Nor did my pleading inspire him, 134 with which, both in dreams and otherwise, 135 I called to him: he cared so little!
136 He fell so low that all means 137 for his salvation were already short, 138 except to show him the lost people.
**Old English:**
133 Ne ðæt bidden ne mihte ða gehelpan, 134 ðe ic him oft on swefnum and on gesyhðum 135 cydde: swa lyt he ðæs gýmde!
136 Swa he feoll niðer, ðæt ælc ðara ðinga 137 wæs to his hæle ða geendungon, 138 buton ðæt he ða forlorenan gesawe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Per questo visitai l’uscio d’i morti, 140 e a colui che l’ha qua sù condotto, 141 li prieghi miei, piangendo, furon porti.
query.result:
**English:**
139 For this reason I visited the gate of the dead, 140 and to the one who led him here above, 141 my prayers, weeping, were carried.
**Old English:**
139 For ðam ic ðæs deades duru gesohte, 140 and ðone ðe hine hider gelædde, 141 ða wæron mine bene wepende brohte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 Alto fato di Dio sarebbe rotto, 143 se Letè si passasse e tal vivanda 144 fosse gustata sanza alcuno scotto
145 di pentimento che lagrime spanda».
query.result:
**English:**
142 The high decree of God would be broken, 143 if Lethe were crossed and such food 144 were tasted without any penalty
145 of repentance that sheds tears.
**Old English:**
142 Hehsta heofonrices wurde tobrocen, 143 gif Letan wurde oferfaren and ðæt lif ðæs treowes 144 wurde onbyrged butan ænigum
145 hrywðe ðæt ða tearas wæron ageotene.
